question: Find all integers \( n \) for which the polynomial \( P(x) = x^3 - nx^2 + (n+1)x - n \) can be factored into three linear factors with integer coefficients. For each such \( n \), express \( P(x) \) as the product of these factors and verify that the resulting polynomial is indeed \( x^3 - nx^2 + (n+1)x - n \).

Let \( f(x) \) be a polynomial with real coefficients such that \( f(0) = 0 \), \( f(1) = 1 \), and for all integers \( n \geq 2 \), the polynomial \( f(n) \) is a positive integer. Find the maximum possible degree of \( f(x) \) such that \( f(x) \) satisfies these conditions.
Find all integers \( n \) such that the polynomial \( P(x) = x^n + (n-1)x - n \) has at least one integer root.
